When Juve signed him (5.5m or something like that?) there was a bit of an uproar over spending so much on a young, unproven player. While I only see Genoa on occasion, I saw the Genoa-Roma match last May. It was the day after my son’s birthday, and two weeks after his ACL surgery and I remember both of us commenting how good Sturaro was. Genoa won, 1 nil. I also saw him in the 1 nil loss vs Roma last December, when Perin got the red and Genoa went down to X – Sturaro held that midfield together, winning the ball and sliding in some very nice through balls. I have a deep appreciation for gritty midfielders, the engine of the team, and Sturaro has all the qualities I admire/respect.
I don’t want to call him the next Gattuso like some are, but I strongly believe he’s going to be a very important player for Juve (and Azzurri) in the future.

Article Title: Federico Mattiello expected to fully recover after gruesome leg injury
Comment Body: Great news, but even with a full physical recovery it will probably take longer for a psychological recovery. Eduardo was never the same player after his compound fracture and it took Aaron Ramsey years to start fulfilling his potential. Arsenal fans were so impatient and critical with Ramsey until last season. We’ll need to be patient and shouldn’t write him off as a potential Juve player for at least 3 seasons. Fingers crossed for him to get his career back on track as soon as possible.

Article Title: Federico Mattiello expected to fully recover after gruesome leg injury
Comment Body: I would like to point out, however, that IF you must have a leg injury, I would gladly take a broken bone over any sort of ligament damage. The psychological hurdle you must overcome after tearing ligaments is much higher than a ‘simple’ bone break.

Article Title: Federico Mattiello expected to fully recover after gruesome leg injury
Comment Body: Definitely – ligament injuries are far worse and harder to repair. With compound fractures like Mattiello’s the bone piercing the skin can create problems with infection and the soft tissue is damaged too. It must take a while to get used to going into challenges again after a break like that. I can’t think of many players other than Ramsey who have come back successfully from compound fractures, while players like Ian Knight or David Busst effectively had their careers ended by them in the past. Fingers crossed for Mattiello.

Article Title: Juventus 1-0 Sassuolo: Paul Pogba at the rescue as Juve extend Serie A lead
Comment Body:
Overall I agree with the ratings, but I would give half a point more to Chiellini and Lichtsteiner. Also, I don’t think Allegri actually made any mistake last night, the problem is that the team is always lacking focus when playing against the "little" at this point of the season. I also thought he made the right call sending in Pepe and Llorente, and although it didn’t work out as I expected (cross from Pepe for the head of Llorente and goal), it was nonetheless Pepe that served Pogba for the goal. The only thing Allegri needs to do is probably motivate the team more, but then again, it seems that at every match that matters (Borussia, Roma the first 70 minutes), Juventus is there, so…
It was reassuring to see Pogba coming back to shape. Not a perfect game, but he made some nice plays, and obviously that shot was awesome. On the other hand, I’m starting to think that Vidal is definitely lost, and that is not a good news. At this point, I don’t know if it’s worth betting on him for the next season (assuming he doesn’t make a comeback in the next few matches).
Anyway, now we need some heavy turnover against Palermo, and then be ready for Dortmund. In Sturaro, Barzagli, Coman, Llorente, maybe De Ceglie and Padoin; also try to give some rest to poor Marchisio (I know that without Marchisio, Pogba and Pirlo our midfield quality would drop drastically, but if there’s a game we can afford to lose this season, is probably the next one with Palermo, so I say go with it).

Article Title: Juventus 1-0 Sassuolo: Paul Pogba at the rescue as Juve extend Serie A lead
Comment Body:
1) We had to really grind it out. For starters, absolute full marks to Sassuolo. Interesting fact, they started the game with 10 Italians on the pitch. They held their organization brilliantly throughout, fought well and with heart. Especially the forwards. Berardi and Zaza didn’t have a lot to do, no real chances fell their way, but man, they have some serious stamina and grinta to chase shadows for 90 minutes the way they do. Very encouraging.
2) Reassuringly, our defense seemed composed. A welcome change after recent games. More worryingly, another game where our midfield failed to click. Its been happening for a while now.. Pogba will have a stunner every now and then and Marchisio will be his usual suave self, but as a whole, just not clicking. Another complete no-show from Vidal. Its the sort of game we used to attribute to Marchisio.. Sure he was there, he didn’t do much wrong. Nowhere near his usual lofty standards. What is wrong with him? I thought Pogba (and hence, the team) woke up in the second half.
3) I’ll just go ahead and say it. Its been a pleasure to watch him and his spirit. He has a very unique set of skills… But the world will not end when Tevez leaves. One glaring weakness I see in his game, is his inability to really link up and get those around him involved. Sure, he’s thrived because of the system this year, but on days like this, the attack just didn’t flow. So clearly the problem isn’t strictly Llorente.
4) I thought Vrsaljko was the man of the match. Delivered in some dangerous crosses, linked up very well with Berardi, overlapped well, seems to be a competent passer.. But I knew all of that already. He looked like a beast in defense yesterday! Tevez’s low cross that Llorente bundled aside, we had no joy down our left flank and a lot of that was down to him. Another year with Sassuolo, and I think we should make a move for him. I’m sure I’ve heard a lot of reports about our interest before. Ideal to replace Licht (who had a poor game according to me.)
5) I think Berardi is ready.. More than anything, I don’t see him growing anymore over here and with these players, no offense to Sassuolo. He clocked his 50th Serie A game yesterday.. Impressive for his age. He did well not to react to some poor fouls from our players too. Bring him in. And I’d say it might be worth sending Coman on loan to them in return. Also, we should seriously consider offloading Llorente for Zaza. His grinta, stamina, strength and effort impress me. I think he’s ready for the step up too.
6) It was ugly at times, but we got the job done. I think securing a clean sheet was crucial. I do think it was a mistake to start Machisio-Vidal-Pogba AGAIN though… Pogba is suspended for palermo, but Marchisio needs rest and badly. Bit of a problem now with only Sturaro and Padoin on the bench. It will be interesting to see what approach Max takes.
+11.. We’re well on our way to #4. Forza Juve!!

Article Title: Juventus 1-0 Sassuolo: Paul Pogba at the rescue as Juve extend Serie A lead
Comment Body:
Didn’t get the chance to comment on the game thread, my son had a game at the same time so I streamed it on my phone from the arena and missed a lot of it. Just rewatched the match in full, so a few comments:
LOVED seeing Nando sing ‘Juve, Storia di Grande Amore’ before the match. Say what you will about his form, few players have embraced the club and team culture like he has.
What is the deal with the Juve pitch? Did it rain in Torino last night? Chiellini slipped again 10’ like he did vs BVB, plus Evra, Zaza and Vrsaljko all lost their footing at one point.
Chiellini two more headers over the traversa, he consistently meets the ball but just can’t direct it down. Juve had 13 corners, and rarely seem to capitalize on them.
The Tevez/Morata tandem still needs time to evolve. At least twice Tevez slipped in a beautiful ball expecting him to make a run and Morata didn’t anticipate it. I thought Carlitos played a very strong match, and as much as I like Morata, can only imagine how good Tevez could be if he had an experienced, world class level striker to interact with on a regular basis.
Max pulled Morata and Pereyra and put in Nando and Pepe for some sort of 4-3-3 variation, with Pepe hugging the touchline but Carlitos rarely went left, it was almost more of a 4-3-1-2 with Tevez the 10 floating about with creative license? I couldn’t really discern what it was.
Speaking of Tevez, I’m almost finished with Alex Ferguson’s autobiography – he also remarked that Tevez is the type of player who needs to play every minute of single match to remain not only sharp, but content. The Berbatov acquisition was to the detriment of his career at United, Sir Alex acknowledged that, but interesting that he said what we’ve all noticed about Carlitos – he has the stamina and desire to play all the time, and is better for it. I for one think Juve will have an extremely difficult time replacing his work rate, grinta, and consistent/reliable productivity unless Juve makes a significant acquisition on the transfer market.
I still get the sense Berardi will remain at Sassuolo next year, but Zaza certainly seems ready for bianconero. Coman could perhaps take over the Sansone role in di Francesco’s 4-3-3.
So Pogba misses Palermo due to his studs up play with Vrsaljko, and he was still fuming about that card minutes afterwards – I thought was a sign of inexerienced temperment, only to see him haul in that ball from Pepe and deliver yet another Pogboom. Just when I think he is still lacking that final coat of polish, he puts one away and gives Juve all 3 points. Amazing instinct and composure for anyone, let alone a soon-to-be 22 yr old. Also post-match he gave his shirt to some middle-aged man with a big France flag, thought that was amusing for some reason.
When Barza came on for Carlitos, I stood up in my living room and gave Apache and no. 15 a big round of applause for his much-anticipated return to the pitch. Max then shifted to 3-5-2, but does anyone wonder if Barza’s return will alter the 4-3-1-2 and revert to a back three again??

Article Title: Juventus 1 - Sassuolo 0: Initial reaction and random observations
Comment Body:
To call Conte’s style as performing below capabilities on the big stage is absurd. First, it denigrates everything he accomplished by reducing the accomplishments to those of the "small stage." Second, Conte had a total of two seasons in the Champions League. In one of them he won his group, and advanced to the quarter finals where he lost out to the eventual champions who were undoubtedly a much better team. The second time, the team didn’t take its chances and was bounced. That’s it for the sample size. At this point however, Allegri hasn’t accomplished anything that Conte didn’t already accomplish, and Allegri’s Juve has not looked like world beaters in the CL either.
Its become fashionable on this site to criticize Conte’s Juve and denigrate his accomplishments. From where I’m sitting Allegri’s Juve isn’t any more consistent, and often doesn’t play any better than Conte’s, and it has yet to accomplish what Conte did.

Article Title: Juventus defender Martin Cáceres to undergo surgery after injuring his left ankle
Comment Body:
i define injury proneness as an innate characteristic on athlete’s body that makes him/her less durable, be it caused by genetics (i don’t have an example off the top of my head), less-than-optimal youth training regime that incurred a weakness in specific spot(s) (pato’s knee comes to mind), and/or less-than-perfect treatments for a one-off injury (pato again, and perhaps the original ronaldo)
i do think Caceres is physically robust, one evidence of which is his all-action playing style, hence i don’t think he’s injury prone as per my understanding above.
however, regarding my previous comment, i can see where there’s no difference at all when injury prone is just defined as "so often injured"

Article Title: Juventus 1-2 Fiorentina: Mohamed Salah's brace makes the difference
Comment Body:
So, this is my first post here, so let me start with a general ‘hi’ to everyone.
Now, on to the game. Needless to say, it was an horrible horrible game. Juve played for like the first thirty minutes, then ten minutes more after taking the second goal. Apart from that, nothing. Confusion, disorder, lots of mistakes (which eventually costed us the game). From yesterday night I would save only Bonucci (the only certainty we had in defense yesterday) and Llorente (who finally scorde again). The rest was terrible. Our B defense (Ogbonna, Padoin, Caceres) is scary, in the sense that I will probably have nightmares about them. Marchisio played his worst game of the year, possibly ever (but he’s only human, hope Allegri gives him some rest), Coman was absolutely not up to the challenge, making lot of mistakes when passing the ball. The boy will have to play much better than that if he wants to get to the main team. Pereyra couldn’t score from two meters without a goalkeeper, I think (apart from that, he’s good, but he will have to start scoring at some point or it’s better if we find someone else). And finally, Allegri made an absolute mess of the game.
I think we can agree that the 4-3-3 is currently not an option (except maybe against teams like Verona or Atalanta or whatever). I’m not saying we could not play like that in the future, I actually like it better than the 4-3-1-2, but the team should devolve some serious effort to it, and it cannot be done in a crucial point of the season. Fiorentina is not a team to be underestimated, as they clearly showed last night, and we should have sticked with the usual plan.
Anyway, we are probably 90% out of Coppa Italia at the moment. Fiorentina is really in good shape right now, and I don’t see them losing with a 2 goal difference at the Franchi. We could do it, if we really wanted it, but then to really want it we should probably be eliminated from Champions at the next game, and I honestly prefer to win against Borussia and then go out of Coppa Italia.
Still, there are a couple of good things to take from this loss.
1) We needed some serious shaking up. Apart from the game with Borussia, we have not been playing well for the last couple of months. Last season Juve started his record-run to the scudetto after the 2-4 at Franchi, I hope this home loss can work the same way.
2) The game clearly showed at least a couple of things we need to fix during the summer market. First, our second lines in defense are not the level they should be. They worked decently so far, but if we want to really fight for two or three titles every year, they will have to go and be replaced. Rugani is a good start, but we need one or two more fixes, possibly relatively young (maybe around 25 years old, it’s a good age for a defender) so they can stay for a few years. Second, we need a new regista to take the place of Pirlo. He is getting old and cannot play with continuity, but without him we often suffer from a lack of order and ideas.

I keep seeing reports from English ‘newspapers’ about Arsenal and Liverpool being interested in Morata for an insane price – in the ballpark of 60m pounds. Now, that alone seems wildly silly and laughable – but it is the comments or coverage of this rumor that tosses me into a blind rage. I keep reading about this rumor in conjunction with references to Real Madrid’s buyback clause. The comment generally goes that Madrid would buy the player back and flip him to, say, Arsenal for the 60m, pocketing at least 35m on top of accounting for the 30m they just paid Juve to get him back.
To a lazy thinker, this seems fantastic! But I ask you this: why would Morata consent to being sold back to Real Madrid without a guarantee of playing time AT MADRID (seeing as how he left for Juve in order to get playing time) and permit them to simply turn right around and sell him instantly to Arsenal? If the player knows Arsenal are interested AND he would rather play in London than Torino, why would he consent to some middle passage through Spain? Even better, why would he even want to leave Juve if hes getting the time he wants and the team is happy with his output/attitude?
If only for the insane amount of obfuscation and poor understanding of how it even operates, I HATE buyback clauses.

Comment Body:
A) Pick a team, preferably an EPL team or Real/Barca/Bayern. Are they lacking in a particular position? Good. That’s your transfer destination.
B) Pick a player in another team that is doing well in that position. Do not pick a one-club-player (unless they are old, and your target team is MLS). Don’t worry if they have only joined for less than a year or have 3 years on their contract remaining.
C) Take a dump on the ground (or if constipated, the latest edition of your "newspaper" will do) and count how many flies land on it within a day. Multiply that number by a million and that is the transfer fee.
D) Flip a coin. If heads, the player is doing badly at the club and wants out – google an image of them after a loss or missed shot. If tails, the club wants the player because they are playing well – google an image of them celebrating (but not with team-mates, as this will shatter the illusion).
